description.narrative: To establish an integrated and multi-sectoral mechanism for the implementation of the Anti-GBV Act

UNDP har hos Sida ansökt om extra medel uppgående till 30 miljoner kronor för att genomföra GRZ-UN Joint P Program on Gender Based Violence in Zambia under perioden 2014 till 2016 (programmet startade 2012). Detta kommer att höja det svenska bidraget till totalt 60 miljoner kronor. Det övergripande målet med insatsen är att etablera en sektoröverskridande mekanism för genomförandet av anti-GBV-lagen från 2011. Insatsens totala budget uppgår till cirka 104124000 kronor. FN bidrar med 13 miljoner kronor; Irish Aid bidrar mer 12,4 miljoner kronor.
The UNDP has applied for additional funding to SIDA of 30 million SEK to implement the GRZ-UN Joint Program on Gender Based Violence in Zambia during the period 2014 to 2016 (the program begun in 2012). This will bring the total Swedish Contribution to 60 million SEK.
The overall objective of the intervention is to establish an integrated and multi-sectoral mechanism for the implementation of the Anti-GBV Act of 2011. The intervention's total budget is approximately SEK102 506 698 000. The UN are contributing SEK 13 000 000; the Irish Aid is contributing SEK12,400,000.

description.narrative: Key achievements over this period include: 1. Completion and operationalisation of six (6) GBV Fast Track Courts in Lusaka, Chipata, Choma, Kabwe, Ndola and Mongu, over and above the agreed upon target of four courts. These courts are all in operation. A Monitoring, Evaluation and Reporting (MER) framework to measure progress on the operations of the fast track courts has been developed. Although the program failed to attain the set target on access to justice (the program target was that 50% of reported cases should be taken to court), the Evaluation Report showed that the fast track courts improved survivors' access to justice. For instance, 73% of the cases handled in the Kabwe fast track courts were disposed within 30 days as compared to the conventional courts which take more than two years on average to be dispose a case. 2. The creation of 21 village led one-stop centres on GBV has brought services closer to the rural population who do not have access to the civil justice system. These have increased awareness on the dangers of GBV using the traditional court system; counselling for survivors; increased access to justice through referral of serious cases to the police and reduced early marriages in target districts. 369 Traditional leaders and customary court adjudicators have been trained in GBV case management. 3. 85,799 people were reached through community, door to door and school sensitisation programs on GBV. 5,815 GBV survivors have been trained by ILO in economic empowerment skills out of which 2,769 started various business initiatives. 4. In terms of improved coordination, 45 GBV task forces comprising of relevant government departments at district level have been created by the Ministry of Gender to promote a harmonised approach and standardised response using the Multi-sectoral GBV guidelines and referral guidelines of 2015. 5. The management of GBV by the health sector has also improved with the training of 1,563 health workers on guidelines in the provision of medical and psychosocial services to GBV survivors. As a result, 9,843 GBV survivors received medical and screening services during the program period in the target districts. in 2017, 6,110 eligible GBV survivors were supported in receiving PEP and EC services, bringing the total number to 11,231 since inception. The program has also supported the Police to revise its training curriculum to include handling GBV as well as in-service training for those already serving. The Judiciary has also been sensitised on gender equality and GBV in particular.
